Developing Strategic Urban Assessments for Selected 
Central and West Asia Developing Member Countries 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

Vice President  L. Jin, Operations 1 
Director General  J. Miranda, Central and West Asia Department (CWRD) 
Director  M. Westfall, Social Sectors Division, CWRD 
   
Team leaders  K. Julian, Principal Urban Development Specialist, CWRD  
  S. Khan, Senior Urban Development Specialist, CWRD

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  This technical assistance (TA) supports the engagement of the Asian Development 
Bank  (ADB)  in  the  urban  sector  in  Central  and  West  Asia.1 The  Central  and  West  Asia 
Department (CWRD) Social Sectors Division (CWSS) plans to carry out a series of country-
level diagnostic studies in its priority sector, urban development, beginning with developing 
member countries (DMCs) to be selected under this TA.2 The approach is to adopt a strategic 
planning  methodology  for  a  structured,  rigorous,  and  fact-based  process  of  analysis  to 
understand problems and take strategic decisions. The studies will assess the urban sector at 
the country level, identify key drivers, collect and interpret data, confirm trends and strategic 
shifts, review models, and put forward recommendations for ADB and its clients. The TA 
output will be strategic urban assessments for three countries in Central and West Asia that 
better inform ADB operations. The TA design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  ADB’s growing involvement in the urban sector—as envisaged under the Medium-Term 
Strategy II (MTS II)3 and the Eminent Persons Group (EPG) report4—calls for comprehensive, 
in-depth strategic sector work. This should break away from past approaches and examine 
sectors in a more strategic way, to provide definitive guidance on ADB’s involvement in each of 
its DMCs. The inclusion of urban infrastructure as a core operational sector demands new 
thinking on modes of assistance in the urban sector, and the adoption of an integrated and 
holistic approach to the problems of urban areas and city regions. 
 
3.  The EPG report places ADB’s future operations in the context of rapid economic growth 
and increasing urbanization in Asia. Trends indicate a major transformation of the region, with 
most people living in urban areas by 2020. Countries will need to confront new risks and 
challenges associated with this change, particularly if they want to remain competitive on the 
global market. These challenges include raising productivity and creating better paying jobs, 
most of which will be in urban areas. This changing environment requires assistance to DMCs 
to  help  transform  traditional  institutions—encouraging  adaptation  to  a  market-driven 
environment in which efficiency and transparency are essential. In a fast-changing region, the 
challenges of urbanization are increasing and call for more innovative, flexible, and responsive 
action by DMCs and their development partners. 
 
4.  Over  the  next  20  years,  Asia’s  cities  will  be  expected  to  accommodate  at  least 
1.2 billion more people, providing a compelling rationale for ADB’s expanded engagement in 
the sector. In Central and West Asia, the importance of developing urban infrastructure and 
services remains high. The cities in Pakistan are characterized by haphazard growth, poor 
service quality, traffic congestion, and inadequate institutional and financial arrangements and 
resources. Water supply and sewerage coverage ranges from 46% to 70%. Water quality is 
poor, and distribution networks are old and suffer from leakage and contamination. There is no 
real sewage treatment in any urban area; most is dumped into the sea or rivers through open 
channels,  creating  serious  environmental  problems.  Most  settlements  have  inadequate 
drainage systems, resulting in flooding during the intense rainy season. Only 60% of solid 
waste generated in Pakistani cities is collected; most is usually deposited on open ground or in

poorly designed dump sites on the outskirts of built-up areas. Movement of people within most 
cities is difficult because of the absence of effective public transport. A backlog of 6 million 
housing  units  nationwide  has  resulted  in  overcrowding  within  the  existing  stock  and  the 
formation of many informal and illegal settlements with minimal basic amenities. Most cities do 
not  have  strategic  development  plans  or  programs  to  support  cultural  heritage  and  the 
environment. 
 
5.  In Central Asia and the Southern Caucasus, many issues in urban areas have not been 
tackled effectively. Following independence, there has been a lack of maintenance for basic 
infrastructure and increased stress placed on the current systems—especially on water and 
waste removal, housing, and transportation. A growing lack of safe water is one of the main 
problems. Many urban areas have distribution networks but water is only supplied a few hours 
each  day.  Waste  removal  practices  are  also  questionable,  as  many  private  dwellers  and 
businesses resort to the use of roadside dumps and open urban spaces. Many cities of Central 
Asia continue to face a severe housing shortage. Others have experienced out-migration of 
productive workers and are characterized by very high unemployment. Urban transportation is 
also a major problem, compounded by high petrol prices and lack of electricity to run trams and 
trolley buses. During winter, cities and towns often experience electricity and energy shortages, 
and people take desperate measures to keep warm. Lack of reliable energy and electricity also 
hinders foreign investment in the region, impeding economic progress. City planning still tends 
to follow the rigid and physical approach adopted under the former Soviet Union. 
 
6.  Urban centers are closely linked with economic growth throughout Central and West 
Asia, and therefore to broader improvements in quality of life. Policies tend to be based on 
trend projections that lack supporting data in many cases. Little is known about the mandates, 
structures, approaches, cost-effectiveness, and comparative advantages of service companies 
operating in the urban sector. The role of the private sector is not clearly defined or understood, 
and  opportunities  for  private  sector  partnerships  in  urban  infrastructure  development  and 
service delivery remain limited. 
 
7.  As a first step towards improving the impact of ADB assistance to the urban sector in 
Central and West Asia, several diagnostic analysis and strategic assessments are required. 
These include the following: 
 
(i)  Clarifying the functions and financing of various levels of local government. 
(ii)  Increasing  cooperation  between  communities,  the  private  sector,  and  local 
governments.  
(iii)  Improving coordination for urban planning and development. 
(iv)  Clarifying the role and capacity of regional and local administrations. 
(v)  Maintaining  economic  growth,  generating  employment,  and  improving  labor 
markets. 
(vi)  Improving the efficiency of service delivery, capturing economies of scale, and 
increasing the role for private sector participation. 
(vii)  Encouraging better public transport and protecting the environment. 
(viii)  Enabling the provision of affordable housing for low-income and urban poor 
groups. 
(ix)  Improving the efficiency and transparency of land markets. 
(x)  Raising sufficient financial resources for investment in urban infrastructure. 
 
8.  Towns and cities are now central to development in Central and West Asia. Innovative 
thinking is required to foster change, which is necessary to improve urban living conditions 
across the region. In support of this, the TA will formulate a strategic assessment that sets out

3
a clear and concise vision for future growth and development of urban settlements, together 
with strategies and actions needed to achieve this. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  By improving the understanding of what drives change in the urban sector and designing 
effective  strategies  to  maximize  and  promote  sustainable  and  equitable  growth  of  urban 
settlements,  the  TA  will  encourage  national  development  and  prosperity;  and  improve  the 
quality of life in towns and cities. The aim of the TA is to develop context-specific, appropriate 
solutions that would have the highest likelihood of delivering measurable development results 
for participating countries and ADB. The output will be highly accessible, quality knowledge 
products to help inform and influence key decision-makers on urban policy in the participating 
DMCs. The outputs will also improve knowledge and understanding of the urban sector for a 
broader audience, and enable ADB to deliver its assistance more effectively and efficiently to 
the urban sector. 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA activities will include the following in each country: (i) a diagnostic analysis of the 
urban sector and the identification of key problem and theme areas; (ii) the preparation of a 
vision for the development of towns and cities, as well as establishing goals and objectives for 
key problem or theme areas; (iii) a strategic road map for development of the urban sector; and 
(iv) a published knowledge product of high quality. 
 
11.  The TA will build on recent sector work undertaken in the selected DMCs. It will draw 
on country strategies and programs, ongoing and proposed urban-related projects, as well as 
documents prepared by other development agencies and the private sector.5 CWSS will 
perform a detailed urban sector literature review prior to the TA to ensure that TA resources 
will be focused on strategic planning and diagnostic activities. 
 
12.  The TA will look to the future, with an eye to developing a new approach for the analysis 
and interpretation of urban problems; and devise effective strategies and interventions to solve 
key problems. The process will be streamlined and focused on a few key issues rather than a 
comprehensive study of the sector. The findings of the analytical work will enhance ADB’s 
sector knowledge, and its ability to engage effectively on policy dialogue with key stakeholders 
in the urban sector of its DMCs. Outputs will be highly “accessible” to DMC clients, civil society, 
and the private sector. The outputs will provide an entry point for partnerships with donors, civil 
society,  and  the  private  sector.  The  TA  should  contribute  to  improving  policy making  and 
forward  planning  of  national  and  provincial  governments,  and  within  the  major  cities  of 
participating countries.  
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The total cost of the TA is estimated to be $1,000,000 equivalent, which will be 
financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding program. The cost estimates and financing 
plan are in Appendix 2. 
                                                 
5  As an example, recent sector work comprises largely sector-specific or project-specific analysis in each country, or 
sector assessments done on a provincial level in the case of Pakistan. The Government of Pakistan has prepared 
Vision 2030 as well as a National Trade Corridor Policy. Building on Vision 2030, Pakistan is also preparing a 
national spatial policy and strategy.

4   
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  ADB will be the Executing Agency for the TA, with CWRD as the nodal point for TA 
activities. ADB will administer the TA in close cooperation with the resident missions and host 
country governments. Collaboration with host country governments will involve leading urban 
research institutions and relevant government planning agencies. Formal no-objection letters 
will be sought from the DMCs, and country-specific work under this TA will commence when 
received. The TA will be implemented over 10 calendar months, starting from March 2008 until 
the end of December 2008. 
 
15.  The TA will be primarily implemented by a consulting firm to be recruited in accordance 
with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). A 
total of 51 person-months of consulting services will be provided for the TA. ADB’s quality and 
cost-based selection method will apply for consulting firms, using the simplified technical 
proposal. About 16.5 person-months of international consultants will be required in the fields 
of  strategic  planning,  urban  economics,  and  change  management.  The  international 
consultants will be expected to spend half of their time in the field, with the balance in their 
home office. A total of 30 person-months of national sector analysts will be required in urban 
economics/finance; infrastructure, service delivery, and environment management; housing, 
urban renewal and social aspects; and governance, institutions and capacity development. 
These  international  and  national  consultants  will  be  required  to  be  associated  with  one 
another in taking on this work. The TA will also draw on selected inputs totaling 4.5 person-
months from three individually contracted urban sector advisors (one in each DMC) who will 
provide high-level peer review and advice to the firm and to ADB. These advisors should be 
highly regarded, locally based urban development specialists with extensive knowledge of 
urban issues.6 Two workshops will be held in each country to ensure the involvement of key 
stakeholders nationwide. The outline terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. A 
work program and staffing table is in Appendix 4. Equipment and office supplies to be financed 
by the TA will be procured by the consultants or ADB in accordance with ADB’s Procurement 
Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time) or other procedures acceptable to ADB. Upon 
completion of the TA, the procured equipment will become the property of ADB. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis 
for Developing Strategic Urban Assessments for selected Central and West Asia developing 
member countries and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
                                                 
6  These urban sector advisors may be international or national consultants, as conditions require. They should be 
drawn from respected universities or research institutions within the DMCs, and will report to ADB staff.

OUTLINE OF TERMS OF REFERENCE 
A.  General 
1.  This technical assistance (TA) will require inputs from international (16.5 person-months) 
and  national  (30  person-months)  consultants,  and  a  local  resource  person  from  each 
participating country. Expertise in strategic planning, economics (including tariff setting and 
regulatory reform), and change management will be required from the international consultants. 
The national consultants will be sector specialists with innovative views on urban economics 
and finance; infrastructure, service delivery, and environment; social aspects, housing and 
urban renewal; and governance, institutions and capacity development. These consultants will 
work under an international consulting firm, and will report to a strategic planning specialist who 
will be the team leader. The TA country teams will also draw expert advice from 4.5 person-
months  of  urban  sector  advisors,  who  will  be  well-respected  and  experienced  urban 
development  specialists  drawn  from  leading  academic  institutions  or  urban  research 
organizations in the participating country. 
 
2.  The consultants will carry out a diagnosis or problem analysis of the urban sector in the 
three participating countries. Goals will be set at various levels, for key themes or functions. 
Ends and means will be discussed and related to one another. The work will be accompanied 
by efforts to obtain the buy-in, support, and commitment of key stakeholders. The process 
requires identifying differences between the current and desired states for the sector, and 
designing actions to eliminate the differences. The Asian Development Bank’s (ADB’s) Central 
and West Asia Department (CWRD) Social Sectors Division (CWSS) will perform a literature 
review prior to the fielding of consultants to ensure that TA time and resources are focused 
primarily on diagnostic analysis and strategic planning. 
3.  The strategic urban assessment for the first participating country will be undertaken as a 
pilot for the new approach. Drawing on lessons learned while preparing this document, the 
consultants will undertake a similar exercise in the second and third participating countries. 
 
B.  Developing Strategic Urban Assessments 
4.  Drawing on existing publications, sector studies, reports, and available statistics and 
data, the consultants will undertake a rapid assessment of the urban sector to determine key 
problem areas and themes in each country. They will assess the status of urban development 
and determine what is likely to happen if no change takes place. With key stakeholders, the 
consultants  will  develop  a  vision  for  each  country’s  urban  future  and  determine  the  core 
strategies needed to achieve this vision. The strategies will be supported with key actions to be 
undertaken to encourage necessary change. 
5.  For each country, the consultants will: 
(i)  Prepare a structured, fact-based, diagnostic analysis of the urban sector that will 
enable a better understanding of problems and lead to strategic decision making. 
This will involve a diagnostic assessment of the urban sector; the identification of 
key drivers; and collection, analysis and interpretation of data. It will outline 
urban trends, patterns, and strategic shifts over the past 10 or more years, and 
their implications for the country and the region. 
(ii)  Develop a vision of each country’s urban future that is supported by government, 
the private sector, representatives of key settlements, and civil society.

Appendix 3  9 
 
(iii)  Determine what changes are needed to achieve the vision, and identify the 
possible role of international development assistance in this change process. 
(iv)  Propose an approach to evaluate the accomplishment of the strategic urban 
assessments. 
(v)  In  close  coordination  with  ADB,  manage  the  drafting,  publication  design, 
graphics, editing, and printing of the strategic urban assessments publication for 
each  country  (estimated  to  be  100  pages  including  text,  graphics,  charts, 
photographs, and other imagery). 
 
1.  Diagnostic Analysis—Assessment and Baseline Information 
6.  The  team  of  consultants  will  assess  the  urban  sector  in  each  country,  gathering 
baseline  information  and  describing  the  current  state  of  the  sector.  This  might  involve 
formulating logic trees, reducing problems to their essential components; forming and testing 
hypotheses; finding key drivers, and addressing problems through a collective approach that 
examines the big picture; focusing on actual problems, gathering and interpreting data—to 
identify and confirm trends, patterns, and issues in the sector. 
7.  Specifically, for each country, the consultants will do the following: 
(i)  Map the spatial distribution of urban settlements. Prepare maps and graphics 
that show the location of urban centers with major communication links (roads, 
railways, airports) and physical features. This should clearly show the changing 
spatial distribution of settlements and the extent of urban expansion over the 
past 25 years. 
(ii)  Scan and collect appropriate and relevant data on the urban sector. This will not 
only cover focused and time-bound statistics but also knowledge relating to the 
key drivers of urban development—the urban economy; transport, municipal 
infrastructure  and  utilities,  and  the  environment;  housing  and  social 
infrastructure; financing urban infrastructure and development; coordination and 
urban management; and institutional and human resource capacities. A review 
and assessment of urban service delivery companies operating in urban areas, 
their mandates, approaches, corporate structures, and relative efficiency and 
effectiveness, will be included. Data collection will include baseline data and 
forward indicators for monitoring the impact of the TA. 
(iii)  Design and compile a series of key indicators for a range of urban settlements. 
This  should  be  expressed  numerically  and  graphically,  and  enable  a 
comparison of today’s values with those of 10 years ago. This would provide 
benchmarks for towns and cities of various sizes, for comparison nationally and 
internationally. The indicators should cover the economy; population, shelter, 
and social development; infrastructure, service delivery, and the environment 
(including transport); coordination, planning, and management; urban finance; 
and capacity. There should be a limited number of indicators (perhaps no more 
than 25) but they should be designed to build a representative profile of each 
settlement that clearly illustrates change over time. 
(iv)  Conduct urban sector situation analysis and problem formulation, and assess 
the implications of trends and change in the key drivers of urban development. 
This will describe what will happen if no change is undertaken. Key problem 
areas and themes within the sector and their causes will be identified. These 
themes are likely to include: (a) appropriate enabling environments; (b) the 
changing economic structure of towns and cities; (c) the problems of the urban

10  Appendix 3   
 
fringe; (d) the incidence of slums, (e) the need for urban renewal and affordable 
housing; (f) improving service delivery; (g) reducing energy use and carbon 
generation,  and  improving  the  physical  environment;  (h)  participatory  urban 
planning  and  management  and  more  effective  coordination  of  urban 
development; (i) raising the necessary finance; (j) making urban governments 
more effective, efficient, and responsive; and (k) promoting cultural diversity and 
heritage. This task will involve the identification of key markets and stakeholders, 
including  organizations  and  groups  (public,  private,  and  civil  society)  active 
within  the  sector  and  the  assessment  of  their  activities.  It  will  also  involve 
establishing the major strengths and weakness of the urban system, along with 
key opportunities and threats to the sector (strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, 
and  threats  [SWOT]  analysis).  The  consultants  will  review  the  appropriate 
enabling environments, regulatory frameworks, structure of organizations, and 
incentive systems; and determine the resources and support needed to effect 
change. Market incentives operating for each stakeholder will be assessed in 
relation to the desired outcomes or end state—the “institutional model”. The 
consultants will compare the baseline/organization profile with the results of the 
SWOT analysis to determine gaps, which will form the basis for the long-term 
strategic plan. The assessment and baseline situation (past, present, and future) 
will end with the identification of the key areas where change is needed. 
 
2.  Desired End State 
8.  This represents where the developing member countries (DMCs) and ADB want to be; 
and requires setting a clear vision for the sector, within each country, with achievable goals, 
objectives, and performance indicators that establish an end state—indicating why change must 
occur. This would be supported by a long-term strategy, which identifies policy and program 
reforms  that  support  the  overall  goals  and  objectives.  Ideally,  this  would  determine  the 
organization(s) for change, as well as their desired structure, incentives, and required resources 
for sustainable operation. This will also involve improving human resources and change in 
organizational culture, improving financial resources for investment, and facilitating an improved 
sociopolitical context. The process needs to be flexible. 
   
9.  For each country, the key steps include the following: 
(i)  Through workshops and other consultations, develop a collective vision for the 
urban  sector  with  key  stakeholders  from  national,  provincial,  and  local 
governments, academe, private sector, and civil society. Two workshops will be 
organized and conducted in each country, one in the capital and the other in a 
major secondary center. 
(ii)  Establish and agree clear values for the urban sector and guiding principles for 
sector development to provide the underlying framework for decision making. 
(iii)  Identify achievable goals for the key theme or problem areas identified earlier. 
Objectives will then be established to support the attainment of each goal. 
 
3.  Road Map 
10.  A road map will detail what needs to be done to achieve the vision. Strategies, action 
plans to implement the strategies, and performance measures will be developed. Specifically, 
the consultants, for each country, will do the following:

Appendix 3  11 
(i)  Develop major strategies necessary to encourage change and attain the vision or 
end state, and identify key actions and priority interventions needed in the short 
and long term. This might relate to capacity building, institutional development 
and legislative reform necessary to create appropriate enabling environments; 
effective markets and instruments to encourage economic development, urban 
renewal,  and  housing;  to  ensure  better  utility  and  service  delivery;  and  to 
encourage environmental improvements, as well as attracting more private and 
public financial resources into the sector. 
(ii)  Provide indicative estimates of the overall investment requirements necessary to 
achieve the established goals and the vision. Assess the likely availability of 
these resources and broadly identify the financing gap. 
(iii)  Identify key interventions and priority projects on the basis of likely resource 
availability and the degree to which they satisfy the goals and objectives that 
support the attainment of the vision. These should be high profile interventions 
that will make a difference. Others can also be recommended for inclusion if the 
resource envelope is enlarged. 
(iv)  Determine priority interventions and investment prospects for external assistance, 
focusing on the potential future role of ADB. This should explore ADB’s role as a 
knowledge provider, as well as a lender. 
(v)  Prepare a draft report after 3 months; and discuss and agree on the strategies, 
priority projects, and interventions with each government and ADB. 
 
4.  Assessing Performance, Evaluation, and Feedback Continuing Change 
11.  The consultants will complete the technical work by establishing an appropriate system 
for assessing how the urban sector is performing against the vision, and how each theme is 
performing against its goal and objectives—i.e., how the country and its development partners 
are performing to effect change in the urban sector. It also should cover the identification of any 
corrective actions necessary. 
12.    For each country, this will involve the following: 
 
(i)  Developing sector performance measures, based on the key indicators and 
themes identified earlier. 
(ii)  Assessing  the  use  of  the  balanced  scorecard  framework,  which  views  the 
sector  from  four  perspectives—learning  and  growth  (capacity),  urban 
development processes, stakeholder satisfaction, and financial resources. 
(iii)  Providing an approach and criteria that would enable the identification of when 
corrective actions are needed and when the assessment should be revised. 
 
5.  Publication Design and Printing 
 13.  The consultants will hire an urban specialist editor to edit the drafts of the three 
strategic urban assessment documents for consistency, structure, content, format, and style. 
In consultation with ADB, appropriate graphics, a publication design, and layout firm will be 
hired to do the following: 
(i)  Prepare the three publications, which will be in the form of readily accessible, 
easy-to-understand documents that provide useful data and analysis in graphic 
and written formats.

12  Appendix 3 
(ii)  Manage the drafting of the strategic urban assessments for the three participating 
countries  in  close  coordination  with  ADB  and  in  line  with  ADB  publication 
guidelines. 
(iii)  Oversee and manage the publications’ design; graphics (maps, satellite imagery, 
charts, tables, and other graphics [including cover design]); editing; translation 
(as necessary); and printing (estimated at 100 pages, including text, graphics, 
charts, photographs, and other imagery).
